Award.AwardTitle: CDI-Type II Beyond Kohn-Sham Density Functional Theory In Time-Dependent Dynamics
Award.AbstractNarration: Kohn-Sham density functional theory (DFT) provides a universal theory of the properties of condensed matter. This theory, for which W. Kohn received the 1998 Nobel Prize, has revolutionized practical calculations. Nevertheless, the theory is based on an average, non-interacting description, and ultimately fails at long time scales. Thus one of the challenges of modern theoretical physics is to develop methods that go beyond this average picture. A practical solution would be transformative. Our multi-disciplinary project addresses this challenge by exploiting real-time approaches. Specifically we will use a combination of real-time DFT and explicit treatments of additional degrees of freedom such as collective coordinates and atomic positions, which are appropriate for problems in materials science and nuclear physics. Such dynamic approaches naturally mix configurations, and provide a common framework for treating long-time behavior in various applications. Though the above extensions are currently computationally demanding, they are likely feasible with expected increases in computer power, together with theoretical and algorithmic advances made possible by the CDI. The broader impacts of a successful methodology are of considerable theoretical and practical importance. For example, going beyond Kohn-Sham DFT could likely enable new discoveries ranging from nuclear structure and reactions to technology including electronics, photonics, and catalysis. In addition, the focus on computational techniques will bring advanced computer science methods, computer codes, and high performance computational methods into theoretical physics and materials science, and will help train a new generation of scientists.

POR.DRECONTENT:
One of the great challenges of modern theoretical physics is to develop techniques that go beyond standard methods based on average, non-interacting descriptions.  For example, Kohn-Sham density functional theory (DFT), for which W. Kohn received the 1998 Nobel Prize, provides a universal theory of the ground state properties, but ultimately fails at long time-scales. Our joint project led by G. Bertsch, J. Rehr, and X. Li has addressed this challenge by exploiting novel real-time approaches and collective coordinates, methods which are applicable to problems in nuclear physics, materials science and quantum chemistry. Such dynamic approaches naturally mix configurations, making it possible to explore configurations beyond an average description.

A key outcome of this joint project is the development of several approaches and algorithms based on time-dependent density functional theory (TDDFT). The Bertsch group has extended TDDFT to model electron response with arbitrarily large fields while avoiding computer-intensive summations over intermediate states. The Rehr group has used a real-time extension (RT-TDDFT) to calculate core level x-ray spectra. The Li group has combined RT-TDDFT and a time-dependent polarizable continuum model to model ultrafast solvated electron dynamics. Other key developments of the Bertsch group include novel approaches for low energy nuclear dynamics, e.g., an improved treatment of the pairing interaction including for the first time, the known three-body force. Other developments of the Rehr group have treated the effects of nuclear motion, which is neglected in conventional DFT.  A key finding is that nuclear motion is essential to explain non-equilibrium properties at the nano-scale, and can be treated by finite temperature real-time DFT/MD. This development may be important in understanding the behavior or supported nano-scale catalysts. Another key development of the Li group is an RT-TDDFT approach to calculate frequency dependent  hyperpolarizabilities  similar to that of  the Rehr group, but with a density matrix  approach. 

In order to facilitate interactions, we have created a Center for Theoretical Quantum Dynamics with periodic talks and visitors.  The synergy provided by these parallel investigations demonstrates how interdisciplinary CDI funding is advantageous for scientific progress. We believe that all of these developments are potentially of theoretical and practical importance, either in physics (nuclear, materials science and chemistry) or technology (materials, electronics, photonics, catalysis, etc).
